text: simone biles welcome to the bbc's
hundred women series thanks so much for
joining us it's been quite an incredible
year for you millions of people watched
you is you won those Gold's in Rio tell
us what it was like when you were
standing on that podium listening to the
national anthem um it's definitely a
whirlwind of emotions because you feel
everything at once you feel how long
you've prepared for that exact moment
and then you feel the pride and joy of
representing your country and then you
finally get the gold and you're standing
there hearing your anthem and it's just
like it's no better feeling you've been
called the greatest gymnast of all time
and it's been quite a journey for you
when you look at yourself in the mirror
do you see a different person do you
feel that you've changed through all of
this um no I still feel like I'm the
same bouncy crazy gymnast that I was
growing up and I'm just a little bit
more disciplined now then I was before
and I've accomplished a lot more cool
your life has changed so much I mean he
met your crush Zac Efron you taking
selfies with Kim Kardashian's and what
other challenges come with that newfound
fame I think it's just learning how to
handle all of it and all the pressure
and all the eyes on you at all times but
other than that I just try to carry
every day the same only one American
woman has ever won gold on the vault
tell us a bit about that meeting at
White House I got to present an award to
them like a surfboard that all the 2016
Olympians signed we were like taking my
funny pictures like throwing fruits and
vegetables is crazy and you cram so much
into your 19 years yeah
tell us a bit about your younger years
because you were adopted by your
grandparents after your biological
mother struggled with addiction I was
adopted at a very young age three years
older five was three and then I went
back and then I came back at five um but
I was so young I hardly remember
anything so whenever I was adopted at a
young age I felt like everyone was
adopted so it never fazed me and it's um
I don't know to me it's never been any
different because it's all I've ever
known and I think growing up as a child
me and my brothers and sisters my
parents have always taught us to strive
to perfection and at the beginning of
the year my mom would always make me
write down goals on a piece of paper and
take it to her um and so that's kind of
how I always like was very well driven
because I always had the next goal in
mind how much of it is in the mind and
how much of it is in just your physical
ability I think anyone can flip upside
down but it's the mental part you have
to get over so I think you can convince
your mind to do anything you and once
you convince your mind then your body
follows along with it so I think I've
always been pretty good at knowing like
sometimes my head gets ahead of my body
actually I'm like I can do this you're
like you know what's wrong you probably
can't mmm but when you were coming up
through the sport at what point did
someone say she's got something that's
special um growing up even whenever I
was eight years old started competing
and everyone always told me I had
something special but I was always a
little bit smaller than all my
competition so I was just like you know
what they just think I'm cute it's fine
whatever
um and everyone would tell me except my
parents because they're like the moment
we tell her then it doesn't register
anymore
so I don't know I never really like
believed it I was just like they're just
saying that I always thought everyone
was just saying it what is your secret
I don't have a secret I guess I've just
always trusted myself and my gymnastics
and I've been very fortunate and blessed
with the body that I've been born with
well on that note
thanks very much Simone biles thanks for
being one of our BBC 100 women thank you
thank you
you
